newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan TV broadcasts to aid Kashmir struggle.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan TV broadcasts to aid Kashmir struggle.

text.p: State television will begin special broadcasts on Friday to Moslem militants fighting Indian rule in the disputed Kashmir region, Pakistani officials said on Wednesday.

Pakistan-controlled Azad (free) Kashmir Prime Minister Sultan Mahmood inaugurated a transmission centre in the state capital of Muzaffarabad on Wednesday, saying it would help boost the morale of the "freedom fighters".

It will beam 3-1/2-hour programmes daily from 6.00 p.m. to 9.30 p.m. (1300-1630 GMT) to Indian-ruled Kashmir via special boosters at three sites in Azad Kashmir, Pakistan Television (PTV) managing director Rana Sheikh told reporters.
PTV programmes can already be viewed in Indian Kashmir but the reception is not good, Kashmiri sources said.

Transmissions from the new centre will begin on the 31st anniversary of Pakistan's second war with India over Kashmir and a day before India holds controversial state assembly elections in the two-thirds of Kashmir that it rules.
Pakistan holds the remaining one-third of the Himalayan region over which the countries have fought two of their three wars since their independence from Britain in 1947.
